100.title: Unhandled root runtime error
100.description:
A root expression is fallible and its [runtime error](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#runtime-errors) isn't handled in the VRL
program.
100.rationale:
VRL is [fail safe](/docs/reference/vrl/#fail-safety) and thus requires that all possible runtime errors be handled.
This provides important [safety guarantees](/docs/reference/vrl#safety) to VRL and helps to ensure that VRL programs
run reliably when deployed.
100.resolution:
[Handle](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#handling) the runtime error by [assigning](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#assigning),
[coalescing](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#coalescing), or [raising](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#raising) the
error.

101.title: Malformed regex literal
101.description:
A [regex literal expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression) is malformed
and thus doesn't result in a valid regular expression.
101.resolution:
Regular expressions are difficult to write and commonly result in syntax errors. If you're parsing a common
log format we recommend using one of VRL's [`parse_*` functions](/docs/reference/vrl/functions/#parse-functions). If
you don't see a function for your format please [request it](https://github.com/vectordotdev/vector/issues/new?labels=type%3A+new+feature). Otherwise, use the
[Rust regex tester](https://rustexp.lpil.uk/) to test and correct your regular expression.

102.title: Non-boolean if expression predicate
102.description:
An [if expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression) predicate doesn't
evaluate to a Boolean.
102.rationale:
VRL doesn't implement "truthy" values (non-Boolean values that resolve to a Boolean, such as `1`) since these
are common foot-guns that can result in unexpected behavior when used in if expressions. This provides important
[safety guarantees](/docs/reference/vrl#safety) in VRL and ensures that VRL programs are reliable once deployed.
102.resolution:
Adjust your if expression predicate to resolve to a Boolean. Helpful functions to solve this include
[`exists`](/docs/reference/vrl/functions#exists) and
[`is_nullish`](/docs/reference/vrl/functions#is_nullish).

103.title: Unhandled fallible assignment
103.description:
The right-hand side of this [assignment](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression)
is fallible (that is, it can produce a [runtime error](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#runtime-errors)), but the error isn't
[handled](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#handling).
103.rationale:
VRL is [fail safe](/docs/reference/vrl/#fail-safety) and thus requires that all possible runtime errors be handled.
This provides important [safety guarantees](/docs/reference/vrl#safety) to VRL and helps to ensure that VRL programs
run reliably when deployed.
103.resolution:
[Handle](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#handling) the runtime error by either
[assigning](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#assigning) it, [coalescing](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#coalescing) it, or
[raising](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#raising) it.

104.title: Unnecessary error assignment
104.description:
The left-hand side of an [assignment expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression)
needlessly handles errors even though the right-hand side _can't_ fail.
104.rationale:
Assigning errors when one is not possible is effectively dead code that makes your program difficult to follow.
Removing the error assignment simplifies your program.

105.title: Undefined function
105.description:
A [function call expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression) invokes an
unknown function.
105.resolution: This is typically due to a typo. Correcting the function name should resolve this.

106.title: Function argument arity mismatch
106.description:
A [function call expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression) invokes a
function with too many arguments.
106.resolution: Remove the extra arguments to adhere to the function's documented signature.

107.title: Required function argument missing
107.description:
A [function call expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression) fails to pass
a required argument.
107.resolution: Supply all of the required function arguments to adhere to the function's documented signature.

108.title: Unknown function argument keyword
108.description:
A [function call expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression) passes an
unknown named argument.
108.resolution: Correct the name to align with the documented argument names for the function.

110.title: Invalid argument type
110.description:
An argument passed to a [function call expression](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#regular-expression)
isn't a supported type.
110.rationale:
VRL is [fail safe](/docs/reference/vrl/#fail-safety) and thus requires that all possible runtime errors be handled.
This provides important [safety guarantees](/docs/reference/vrl#safety) to VRL and helps to ensure that VRL programs
run reliably when deployed.
110.resolution:
You must guarantee the type of the variable by using the appropriate
[type](/docs/reference/vrl/functions/#type-functions) or [coercion](/docs/reference/vrl/functions/#coerce-functions) function.

111.title: Unhandled predicate error
111.description:
A predicate is fallible and its [runtime error](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#runtime-errors) isn't handled in the VRL
program.
111.rationale:
VRL is [fail safe](/docs/reference/vrl/#fail-safety) and thus requires that all possible runtime errors be handled.
This provides important [safety guarantees](/docs/reference/vrl#safety) to VRL and helps to ensure that VRL programs
run reliably when deployed.
111.resolution:
[Handle](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#handling) the runtime error by [assigning](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#assigning),
[coalescing](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#coalescing), or [raising](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#raising) the
error.

203.title: Unrecognized token
203.description: Your VRL program contains a token (character) that the VRL parser doesn't recognize as valid.

204.title: Unrecognized end-of-file (EOF)
204.description:
The VRL parser has reached the end of the program in an invalid state, potentially due to a
typo or a dangling expression.
204.resolution: Make sure that the last expression in the program is valid.

205.title: Reserved keyword
205.description: You've used a name for a variable that serves another purpose in VRL or is reserved for potential future use.

206.title: Invalid numeric literal
206.description: The VRL compiler doesn't recognize this numeric literal as valid.

207.title: Invalid string literal
207.description: Your VRL program contains a string literal that the VRL parser doesn't recognize as valid.
207.resolution: Make sure that your string is properly enclosed by single or double quotes.

examples.title: Invalid string literal
examples.diff:
- "Houston, we have a problem'
+ "Houston, we have a problem"

208.title: Invalid literal
208.description: The VRL compiler doesn't recognize this literal value as valid.

209.title: Invalid escape character
209.description: Your string includes an escape character that the VRL compiler doesn't recognize as valid

300.title: Unexpected type
300.description: The VRL compiler expected a value of a specific type but found a different type.

301.title: Type coercion error
301.description: This value can't be coerced into the desired type.

302.title: Remainder error
302.description: These two types can't produce a remainder.

303.title: Multiplication error
303.description: These types can't be multiplied together

304.title: Division error
304.description: The left-hand value can't be divided by the right-hand value.

305.title: Divide by zero
305.description: You've attempted to divide an integer or float by zero.
305.rationale:
Unlike some other programming languages, VRL doesn't have any concept of infinity, as it's
unclear how that could be germane to observability data use cases. Thus, dividing by zero
can't have any meaningful result.
305.resolution:
If you know that a value is necessarily zero, don't divide by it. If a value *could* be
zero, capture the potential error thrown by the operation:

```coffee
result, err = 27 / .some_value
if err != nil {
	# Handle error
}
```

306.title: NaN float
306.description: Floats in VRL can't be NaN (not a number).

307.title: Addition error
307.description: These two values can't be added together.

308.title: Subtraction error
308.description: The right-hand value can't be subtracted from the left-hand value.

309.title: Or expression error
309.description: These two values can't be combined into an or expression.

310.title: And expression error
310.description: These two values can't be combined into an and expression.

311.title: Greater than error
311.description: These two values can't be used in a greater than expression.

312.title: Greater than or equal to error
312.description: These two values can't be used in a greater than or equal to expression.

313.title: Less than error
313.description: These two values can't be used in less than expression.

314.title: Less than or equal to error
314.description: These two values can't be used in a less than or equal to expression.

315.title: mutation of read-only value
315.description: This value is read-only and cannot be deleted or mutated.

400.title: Unexpected expression
400.description: The VRL compiler encountered an expression type that wasn't expected here.

401.title: Invalid enum variant
401.description:
VRL expects an enum value for this argument, but the value you entered for the enum is
invalid.
401.resolution:
Check the documentation for this function in the [VRL functions
reference](/docs/reference/vrl/functions) to see which enum values are valid for this argument.

402.title: Expected static expression for function argument
402.description:
VRL expected a static expression for a function argument, but a dynamic one was provided (such as a variable).

VRL requires static expressions for some function arguments to validate argument types at
compile time to avoid runtime errors.
402.resolution: Replace the dynamic argument with a static expression.

403.title: Invalid argument
403.description: An invalid argument was passed to the function. The error string will contain more details about what was invalid.
403.resolution: Check the error string for this error to see what was invalid.

601.title: Invalid timestamp
601.description:
The provided [timestamp literal](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#timestamp) is properly
formed (i.e. it uses `t'...'` syntax) but the timestamp doesn't adhere to [RFC 3339](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339) format.
601.resolution: Bring the timestamp in conformance with [RFC 3339](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339) format.

620.title: Aborting infallible function
620.description: You've specified that a function should abort on error even though the function is infallible.
620.rationale:
In VRL, [infallible](/docs/reference/vrl/errors/#handling) functionsâ€”functions that can't failâ€”don't require error
handling, which in turn means it doesn't make sense to abort on failure using a `!` in the function call.
620.resolution: Remove the `!` from the function call.

630.title: Fallible argument
630.description: You've passed a fallible expression as an argument to a function.
630.rationale:
In VRL, expressions that you pass to functions as arguments need to be infallible themselves. Otherwise, the
outcome of the function would be indeterminate.
630.resolution:
Make the expression passed to the function infallible, potentially by aborting on error using `!`, coalescing
the error using `??`, or via some other method.

631.title: Fallible abort message expression
631.description: You've passed a fallible expression as a message to abort.
631.rationale: An expression that you pass to abort needs to be infallible. Otherwise, the abort expression could fail at runtime.
631.resolution: Make the expression infallible, potentially by handling the error, coalescing the error using `??`, or via some other method.

640.title: No-op assignment
640.description: You've assigned a value to something that is neither a variable nor a path.
640.rationale:
All assignments in VRL need to be to either a path or a variable. If you try to assign a value to, for example,
underscore (`_`), this operation is considered a "no-op" as it has no effect (and is thus not an assignment at
all).
640.resolution: Assign the right-hand-side value to either a variable or a path.

examples.title: No-op assignment
examples.diff:
- 	_ = "the hills are alive"
+# 	.movie_song_quote = "the hills are alive"

650.title: Chained comparison operators
650.description: You've chained multiple comparison operators together in a way that can't result in a valid expression.
650.rationale:
Comparison operators can only operate on two operands, e.g. `1 != 2`. Chaining them together, as in
`1 < 2 < 3`, produces a meaningless non-expression.
650.resolution:
Use comparison operators only on a left-hand- and a right-hand-side value. You *can* chain comparisons together
provided that the expressions are properly grouped. While `a == b == c`, for example, isn't valid,
`a == b && b == c` *is* valid because it involves distinct Boolean expressions.

651.title: Unnecessary error coalescing operation
651.description:
You've used a coalescing operation (`??`) to handle an error, but in this case the left-hand
operation is infallible, and so the right-hand value after `??` is never reached.
651.rationale:
Error coalescing operations are useful when you want to specify what happens if an operation
fails. Here's an example:

```coffee
result = op1 ?? op2
```

In this example, if `op1` is infallible (that is, it can't error) then the `result` variable
if set to the value of `op1` while `op2` is never reached.
651.resolution:
If the left-hand operation is meant to be infallible, remove the `??` operator and the
right-hand operation. If, however, the left-hand operation is supposed to be fallible,
remove the `!` from the function call and anything else that's making it infallible.

652.title: Only objects can be merged
652.description: You're attempting to merge two values together but one or both isn't an object.
652.rationale:
Amongst VRL's available types, only objects can be merged together. It's not clear what it
would mean to merge, for example, an object with a Boolean. Please note, however,
that some other VRL types do have merge-like operations available:

* Strings can be [concatenated](/docs/reference/vrl/expressions/#concatenation) together
* Arrays can be [appended](/docs/reference/vrl/functions#append) to other arrays

These operations may come in handy if you've used [`merge`](/docs/reference/vrl/functions#merge) by
accident.
652.resolution:
Make sure that both values that you're merging are VRL objects. If you're not sure whether
a value is an object, you can use the [`object`](/docs/reference/vrl/functions#object) function to
check.

660.title: Non-Boolean negation
660.description: You've used the negation operator to negate a non-Boolean expression.
660.rationale:
Only Boolean values can be used with the negation operator (`!`). The expression `!false`, for example, produces
`true`, whereas `!"hello"` is a meaningless non-expression.
660.resolution: Use the negation operator only with Boolean expressions.

701.title: Call to Undefined Variable
701.rationale: Referencing a variable that is undefined results in unexpected behavior, and is likely due to a typo.
701.resolution: Assign the variable first, or resolve the reference typo.

801.title: Usage of deprecated item
801.description: The referenced item is deprecated. Usually an alternative is given that can be used instead.
801.rationale: This will be removed in the future.
